Award.AwardTitle: Process Matters: Legislative Procedure in the United Nations General Assembly

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project proposes that thinking of the assembly as a legislature-specifically by focusing on its process and procedure-can significantly expand our understanding of state behavior and influence in international organizations. The United States spends tens of millions of dollars on United Nations related activities each year. This project provides a potential avenue of new understanding that could alter the outcome of national security and other diplomatic situations in the future. By better explaining the logic and motives behind state behavior, it could provide US decision makers with a more informed means of strategically navigating UN pathways to successful outcomes.

A wealth of international relations literature focuses on roll call voting outcomes in the United Nations General Assembly. The United Nations General Assembly facilitates cooperation between states in the international system and provides a forum for states to send important signals. The institution helps states manage collective resources, lowers the transaction costs of joint decision-making, and increases the transparency with which decisions are made regarding war and peace. In order to understand how state preferences are aggregated within the United Nations, scholars have focused much attention on adoption votes at the end of the process. But final adoption is only one?arguably small?part of the story; much of the conflict and negotiation that occurs in the UNGA happens before agenda items and resolutions ever reach the plenary floor. This project will thus help better understand the uncover sources of power and dimensions of conflict that have gone undetected.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A wealth of international relations literature focuses on roll call voting in the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA) (e.g., Kim & Russett 1996, Voeten 2000, Carroll et al. 2015, Dreher & Jensen 2013). In this way, international organization (IO) scholars borrow insights from research on domestic legislative decision-making. Although there are differences between the UNGA and domestic legislatures—most notably, the ability to enforce policy decisions—the literature on domestic legislatures has significant potential to influence our understanding of politics in IOs like the United Nations. Domestic legislative studies research pays special attention to the policymaking process, which provides a means for understanding the sources and consequences of power in legislatures. In our grant proposal, we argued that by thinking of the UNGA as a legislature—in other words, by focusing on its process and procedure—we can significantly expand our understanding of power and influence in international organizations.

In the UNGA, what ends up on the agenda—and what does not—can have important international consequences. If, for example, a specific paragraph fails to appear in a UNGA resolution, the content of the signals sent by countries’ votes for or against that resolution change. Alternatively, if a state has a chance to vote on (or propose) the insertion of specific language into a resolution—i.e. an amendment—that vote is itself an opportunity to send a signal about a specific policy position. This attention to process—agenda setting, amendments, sponsorship of draft resolutions, and other procedure that occurs prior to the final adoption vote on resolutions in the plenary—is precisely why it is important to treat the UNGA as a legislature. Our grant proposal pointed out that previous data on UNGA voting focused on only plenary voting, thus preventing scholars from testing the implications of theory regarding legislative process.

The primary focus of our grant request centered on new data collection to remedy this concern, specifically, the collection of original data on UNGA agenda proposals and votes including (1) Agenda Setting and Allocation data, (2) Disposition data, and (3) Plenary and Committee Voting data.

The NSF grant supported the coding and cleaning of UNGA procedures and outcome data for public use. We have completed the collection of all data as described in the grant proposal: (1) Agenda Setting and Allocation data, (2) Disposition data, and (3) Plenary and Committee Voting data. Using the resources available to us at UC Merced, we are currently collating the data into a handful of convenient forms that will be of interest to both scholars and non- scholars. We plan to post those data for public use on a project website and with the Inter-Iniversity Consortium for Political and Social Research (ICPSR). 

Our findings are as yet preliminary, but have been presented at multiple academic conferences both prior to and since the origination of the NSF grant. We currently have one introductory paper from the project under review and are working on several substantive research papers and a book manuscript using the data.

The project provided an opportunity for a graduate student and eight undergraduate students in political science at UC Merced---many of them underrepresented minorities in the field---with experience collecting data on United Nations General Assembly procedures and outcomes. In addition to learning about the data collection process and how to make raw data ready for public access, students had the opportunity to gain facility with Microsoft Office Programs and an introduction to Stata statistical analysis software.
